question.body: When RBCs are broken down at the end of their lifespan, most of the hemoglobin components are recycled. Which component is not recycled?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Iron is recycled by transporting it on tranferrin back to bone marrow.

Correct. The heme group is ultimately broken down into bilirubin and urobilin, which are excreted from the body in urine and feces. These breakdown products are responsible for the yellow color of urine and the brown color of feces.
Incorrect. The globin proteins can be broken down into their amino acids to be re-used in making other proteins.

part.hint: The body is good at recycling common structures and ions.

question.body: Red blood cells have a limited lifespan because __________.

multiple_choice.choice: they cannot “fix” damage that accumulates over time
they express self proteins that degrade, causing immune cells to attack them
their high mitotic rate causes mutations that accumulate over time

response.feedback: Incorrect. Apoptosis is programmed cell death, which is not what RBC experience.
Correct. Because they do not have nuclei, as damage occurs to proteins, they cannot replace them.
Incorrect. The self-proteins (antigens) that determine blood type do not degrade and are not attached by immune cells; they would only cause problems during mismatched transfusion as discussed later.
Incorrect. Mature RBC do not divide.

part.hint: Most long-living cells would not live as long if they could not do this.
